message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Transfer Learning in Deep Reinforcement Learning: A Survey
Paper Abstract: Reinforcement learning is a learning paradigm for solving sequential decision-making problems. Recent years have witnessed remarkable progress in reinforcement learning upon the fast development of deep neural networks. Along with the promising prospects of reinforcement learning in numerous domains such as robotics and game-playing, transfer learning has arisen to tackle various challenges faced by reinforcement learning, by transferring knowledge from external expertise to facilitate the efficiency and effectiveness of the learning process. In this survey, we systematically investigate the recent progress of transfer learning approaches in the context of deep reinforcement learning. Specifically, we provide a framework for categorizing the state-of-the-art transfer learning approaches, under which we analyze their goals, methodologies, compatible reinforcement learning backbones, and practical applications. We also draw connections between transfer learning and other relevant topics from the reinforcement learning perspective and explore their potential challenges that await future research progress.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Links: [{"title":"Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Reinforcement learning from human feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Reinforcement_learning_from_human_feedback"},{"title":"Multi-agent reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-agent_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Self-play (reinforcement learning technique) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-play_(reinforcement_learning_technique)"},{"title":"Model-free (reinforcement learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model-free_(reinforcement_learning)"},{"title":"Category:Reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Deep reinforcement learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_reinforcement_learning"},{"title":"Q-learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Q-learning"},{"title":"Self-supervised learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-supervised_learning"},{"title":"Imitation learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Imitation_learning"}]

## Overview

Reinforcement learning (RL) is concerned with how an intelligent agent should take actions in a dynamic environment in order to maximize a reward signal.(no content)Reinforcement learning is one of the three basic machine learning paradigms, alongside supervised learning and unsupervised learning.

## Key Concepts

While supervised learning and unsupervised learning algorithms respectively attempt to discover patterns in labeled and unlabeled data, reinforcement learning involves training an agent through interactions with its environment.(no content)The agent makes decisions between trying new actions to learn more about the environment (exploration), or using current knowledge of the environment to take the best action (exploitation).

## Applications

Reinforcement learning has been applied successfully to various problems, including energy storage, robot control, photovoltaic generators, backgammon, checkers, Go (AlphaGo), and autonomous driving systems.(no content)Deep reinforcement learning has been used for a diverse set of applications including but not limited to robotics, video games, natural language processing, computer vision, education, transportation, finance and healthcare.

## Notable Achievements

AlphaGo, a computer program trained with deep RL to play Go, became the first computer Go program to beat a human professional Go player without handicap on a full-sized 19×19 board in 2015.(no content)OpenAI Five, a program for playing five-on-five Dota 2 beat the previous world champions in a demonstration match in 2019.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

I've completed the web search for "robotics". Here are the results:

## Overview

Robotics is the interdisciplinary study and practice of the design, construction, operation, and use of robots.(no content)Within mechanical engineering, robotics is the design and construction of the physical structures of robots, while in computer science, robotics focuses on robotic automation algorithms.

## Key Components

Robotics usually combines three aspects of design work to create robot systems: mechanical construction, electrical components that power and control the machinery, and software (programs that determine how and when a robot does something).

## Types of Robots

The search results cover several specialized areas of robotics:

- **Soft Robotics**: A subfield of robotics that concerns the design, control, and fabrication of robots composed of compliant materials, instead of rigid links.

- **Robotic Arms**: A type of mechanical arm, usually programmable, with similar functions to a human arm.

- **Hexapod Robots**: A mechanical vehicle that walks on six legs, and since a robot can be statically stable on three or more legs, a hexapod robot has a great deal of flexibility in how it can move.

## Applications and Industry

In the 21st century, investment in robotics companies has grown due to increasing demand for automation. Notable robotics companies include Hanson Robotics, which develops humanoid robots, and various organizations running educational competitions like VEX Robotics.

Web search results for query: "deep neural networks"

Links: [{"title":"Deep neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Deep_neural_networks&redirect=no"},{"title":"Neural network (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_network_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Deep learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deep_learning"},{"title":"Quantum neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quantum_neural_network"},{"title":"Physics-informed neural networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Physics-informed_neural_networks"},{"title":"Graph neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Graph_neural_network"},{"title":"Spiking neural network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Spiking_neural_network"},{"title":"Attention (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attention_(machine_learning)"},{"title":"Neural style transfer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neural_style_transfer"},{"title":"Tensor (machine learning) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tensor_(machine_learning)"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about deep neural networks:

## Definition

A network is typically called a deep neural network if it has at least two hidden layers.(no content)The adjective "deep" refers to the use of multiple layers (ranging from three to several hundred or thousands) in the network.

## Core Concepts

In machine learning, a neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks. A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)In machine learning, deep learning focuses on utilizing multilayered neural networks to perform tasks such as classification, regression, and representation learning.

## Applications

These architectures have been applied to fields including computer vision, speech recognition, natural language processing, machine translation, bioinformatics, drug design, medical image analysis, climate science, material inspection and board game [analysis].

## Training

Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network. During the training phase, ANNs learn from labeled training data by iteratively updating their parameters to minimize a defined loss function.

Web search results for query: "transfer learning"

Links: [{"title":"Transfer learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_learning"},{"title":"Transfer of learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transfer_of_learning"},{"title":"Negative transfer (memory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Negative_transfer_(memory)"},{"title":"Curriculum learning - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Curriculum_learning"},{"title":"Knowledge transfer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_transfer"},{"title":"Botetourt Medal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Botetourt_Medal"},{"title":"Intersegmental General Education Transfer Curriculum - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Intersegmental_General_Education_Transfer_Curriculum"},{"title":"Knowledge distillation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Knowledge_distillation"},{"title":"Cleveland Jackson - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cleveland_Jackson"},{"title":"Open Learning Institute of British Columbia - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Open_Learning_Institute_of_British_Columbia"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about transfer learning:

## Transfer Learning Overview

Transfer learning (TL) is a technique in machine learning (ML) in which knowledge learned from a task is re-used in order to boost performance on a related task.(no content)For example, for image classification, knowledge gained while learning to recognize cars could be applied when trying to recognize trucks.

## Applications

Transfer learning has been applied to cancer subtype discovery, building utilization, general game playing, text classification, digit recognition, medical imaging and spam filtering. Additionally, transfer learning is possible between electromyographic (EMG) signals from the muscles and classifying the behaviors of electroencephalographic (EEG) brainwaves, from the gesture recognition domain to the mental state recognition domain, and this relationship worked in both directions.

## Historical Development

In 1981, a report considered the application of transfer learning to a dataset of images representing letters of computer terminals, experimentally demonstrating positive and negative transfer learning.(no content)Ng said in his NIPS 2016 tutorial that TL would become the next driver of machine learning commercial success after supervised learning.

The search results also included information about related concepts like knowledge distillation and the broader concept of transfer of learning in educational psychology contexts.

Links: [{"title":"General game playing - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_game_playing"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Machine learning in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Machine_learning_in_video_games"},{"title":"Category:Game artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Game_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Category:Video games about artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Video_games_about_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"AlphaGo - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AlphaGo"},{"title":"Video game bot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Video_game_bot"},{"title":"Alternate reality game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alternative_reality_game"},{"title":"Iconary - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iconary"},{"title":"Videoball - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Videoball"}]

I've performed a web search on "game-playing artificial intelligence" and found comprehensive information on the topic. Here's what the search revealed:

## Overview

General game playing (GGP) is the design of artificial intelligence programs to be able to play more than one game successfully.(no content)For many games like chess, computers are programmed to play these games using a specially designed algorithm, which cannot be transferred to another context.

## Key Applications

**Board Games:** Chess is a turn-based strategy game considered a difficult AI problem due to computational complexity, often solved with some form of a Minimax Tree Search. Notable achievements include AI agents beating professional human players, such as the historic 1997 Deep Blue versus Garry Kasparov match. Similarly, AlphaGo's March 2016 victory was a major milestone in artificial intelligence research.
